{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3505358,"name":"Mahi Madhan Kumar","username":"Stormbreaker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stormbreaker/{size}/268248_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-07T20:18:59.007Z","cooked":"

Hey everyone,

Our team is looking to push our swerve drive to its absolute limit in both auto and teleop. I know about Choreo for path planning, but I’m really curious about what other teams do to get the most out of their swerve beyond just following paths. There’s a lot that goes into making swerve feel as smooth, responsive, and consistent as possible, and I’d love to hear what strategies people use to refine their code.

For teleop, what kinds of tuning or optimizations have made a real difference for your drivers? Things like how you handle inputs, smooth out transitions, or make the robot feel more natural to control. On the auto side, what have you done to make paths flow better, reduce stop-and-start behavior, and get the cleanest possible movement? Anything that helps swerve feel more dialed in and takes advantage of its full potential is what I’m looking for.

Would love to hear what has worked for other teams, whether it’s small adjustments that made a big difference or more advanced techniques that really push performance. If you’ve got any examples or suggestions, I’d really appreciate it!

The programmers use SYS ID to capture logs from your robot by running a series of motion tests on your drive base. You need a full field and alot of carpet to do this correctly. Once SYS ID is finished, you take the numbers and logs to tune your swerve drive train PIDs.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Introduction to System Identification

What is “System Identification?”: In Control Theory, system identification is the process of determining a mathematical model for the behavior of a system through statistical analysis of its inputs...

Slew Rate Limiters isprobably the easiest way to optimize and smooth out your control! Just add them to your x/y controller inputs and modify the rate of change to your liking

Just a slight clarification, you don’t need a full field. I just think you need space on similarish carpet to be able to run the test.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-02-10T17:08:49.654Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":133,"readers_count":132,"score":51.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":485584,"topic_slug":"extracting-the-maximum-performance-from-swerve-in-software-auto-and-teleop-strategies","display_username":"vargoose84","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":3040,"username":"Chris_Elston","name":"Chris_Elston","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chris_elston/{size}/256883_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics"},"post_url":"/t/extracting-the-maximum-performance-from-swerve-in-software-auto-and-teleop-strategies/485584/4","custom_user_title":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3522398,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-10T17:16:38.149Z","cooked":"
  1. Use higher frequency odom on CTRE CANivore, with Krakens, and CANCoders.
  2. Find and apply your coupling ratio
  3. SysId the drive and angle motors ON CARPET and test the PID and Feedforward.
  4. Tune your discretization
  5. Tune your angular velocity coefficient.
  6. Tune your path following translation and rotation PID using Telemetry measuring your setpoint and measured data. Like PathPlanner Telemetry

Really you need to start from a CTRE Swerve Gen Project

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-02-10T17:27:36.542Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":121,"readers_count":120,"score":49.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485584,"topic_slug":"extracting-the-maximum-performance-from-swerve-in-software-auto-and-teleop-strategies","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/extracting-the-maximum-performance-from-swerve-in-software-auto-and-teleop-strategies/485584/5","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3522403,"name":"Drew Williams","username":"jreneew2","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jreneew2/{size}/135239_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-10T17:24:05.723Z","cooked":"

Make sure to do steps 3-6 with your final weight (bumpers, all mechanisms, etc)
